MESSAGE: Hi Mrs. Babler! Let me tell you about the Parable of the Talents (Matthew 25:14-30)!
A master was leaving his home on a journey, when he entrusted his wealth among his servants (Matthew 25:14).
According to their skills, he gave each servant a different amount of talents (an amount of money like gold).
The first he gave five talents, the second he gave two, and the last he gave one (Matthew 25:15).
Then, he set off on his journey.
While he was away, each servant chose how to handle his wealth.
The first servant put his money to work and gained five talents more (Matthew 25:16).
The second one did the same, doubling the wealth he had been given (Matthew 25:17).
The last one, however, chose a different path. The last servant buried his talent deep in the master’s ground, concealing the wealth from plain sight (Matthew 25:18).
Like all actions, each of the servants’ actions came with consequences, both good and bad.
When the master arrived home from his journey, he asked each servant what they did with the money they had been entrusted with.
When the first two servants told their master what they had done with the wealth, the master rewarded them, saying,

However, when the last servant told the master what he had done with the talent he had been loaned, the master was furious. He was angry that the servant didn’t even try to increase the value of the money.
The master then gave the servant who had ten talents, the talent of the servant who only had one, simultaneously rewarding and punishing those who deserved it (Matthew 25:28).
This parable subtly teaches a lesson of taking risks. The first two servants took a risk, putting their money to work, while the last servant didn’t even put any effort.

The master was angry at the servant for burying the money in the master’s ground, not even depositing it to the bank so that the master could “receive it back with interest” because he didn’t even put in the effort to increase the value of the talent (Matthew 25: 26).

Like the master, the Lord doesn’t want us to be cowards. He wants us to take risks for his greater glory. He wants us to work hard and try our best in everything we do. Even though the outcome may not have been as we have hoped, God will still reward us for putting in an effort.
Simply trying and taking a risk is more favourable in God’s eyes than being a coward and not even taking a risk, even if it is for a better future, even if it is for the greater glory of God.
How can we apply this to our everyday lives?

We can apply this parable to our day-to-day lives; because like these servants, we were also given talents. The Lord, our master, distributed certain talents to his specific people. The master entrusted his servants with his wealth, while he was away on his journey, leaving them to handle their talents however they wished.

God entrusted us with his talents, leaving us here on Earth, to handle the talents he has given us, however we wished. In both instances, their master and our God entrusted us with complete freedom, complete control for these valuables, valuables that neither belong to us, nor the servants, but to God, our master.

Even though God has entrusted us with his talents, giving us complete freedom to do whatever we wish with them, he still has preferences on how we use these talents. He entrusted us with these talents, in hopes of his people using them to glorify him and his name.
Although it may seem daunting, to have a being of such great power entrust us with talents of such value, there are many ways that we can simply glorify him.
For instance, if God entrusted his talent of music with his people, they could use this talent to sing, play, or create songs, praising him and sharing his greatness with people all around the world.

If someone had a talent of being able to speak many different languages, they could preach God’s Word in many different areas, since they are able to easily communicate with them through the gift of language.
Although these situations can be quite intimidating, there are many smaller and simpler actions that can be done that still please the Lord, such as inviting a friend to church.

Even though it may seem that a small action like this, does not require any form of skill or talent, it still does. Asking someone to attend church with you requires the talent of courage and some form of audacity.

Since God and the topic of faith is quite controversial in our world today, bringing up the subject of Christianity does require the talent of courage and audacity, a talent that can be quite misunderstood.
Like the Parable of the Talents, we should use our talents for only one, primary reason.
Like the Parable of the Talents, we should use our talents for only one, primary reason.
I'm the master, and I entrust you all, faithful servants, with my wealth.
For you, I entrust five talents.
For you, I entrust two talents.
For you, I entrust one talent.
“‘Well done, good and faithful servant! You have been faithful with a few things; I will put you in charge of many things. Come and share your master’s happiness!’” (Matthew 25:21;23).
I'm Servant 1
I'm Servant 3
I'm Servant 2
